body:
Are you saying that I need to use_rasp=True and do cross compiling on my
local machine which is an x64 machine?
If yes, how do I do the cross compile on my host machine? I don't think my
local host has installation of gcc for arch64

Thanks,

So OpenCL works properly on my firefly system. Now how can I run deploy_model_on_rasp.py with OpenCL enabled?

Thanks,
Thanks for pointing this out. It should be able to be solved by https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/pull/163
On Ubuntu 16.04 the LLVM pre-build are built with gcc5, which have a different ABI of std::string as gcc4x, this could be the cause of your problem: build the project with gcc5

Not sure where to start to enable OpenCL in deploy_model_on_rasp.py.

I can run deploy_model_on_rasp.py in local mode ie, use_rasp=False on firefly 3399. Is the code below which needs to change to generate opencl instead of llvm for cpu?


use_rasp = False

if use_rasp:
    target = "llvm -target=armv7l-none-linux-anueabihf -mcpu=cortex-a53 -mattr=+neon"
else:
    target = "llvm"

with tvm.target.rasp():
    graph, lib, params = nnvm.compiler.build(
        net, target, shape={"data": data_shape}, params=params)

Thanks

For now, the NNVM compiler routine via topi is not optimized under ARM openCL.  So it is not enabled 

We can enable it by adding opencl schedule for ops under https://github.com/dmlc/nnvm/blob/master/python/nnvm/top/
 which calls into topi, in theory we could reuse some of the schedules for CUDA, but they won't be optimal
To get the full power of opencl we will need to start by tuning OpenCL perf of topi under these GPUs. After things are done with the single kernel perf. Enabling them in NNVM will be straight forward

It looks like not a small effort to enable OpenCL. I will wait for OpenCL
enabled demo example first and then do finetuning on firefly3399 by myself
later


Thanks,

this is mainly because python do not allow simple overload of equal operator, we need to use tvm.equal instead

You should be able to find everything you need in here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/web

TVM is a bit non-typical than a traditional js package as it allows you to "generate new javascript code" from TVM DSL (which current supported in python and c++ so all infrastructure can be reused). We provide a simple runtime to allow you to dynamically plugin the generated code and even run it on the browser which is remotely connected to your python script.

yes, we are looking into it. The auto schedule pattern for GPU and multi-core CPU could go beyond what pattern we can use for image processing works and we are gaining some experience on what new changes need to be done here

You can explore the web backend here https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/tree/master/web

For now, we did not yet take effort into WebGL generation because OpenGL's limitation in terms of expressing compute kernels. We do support Metal code generation, which effectively makes it work with WebGPU.

The web assembly code generation takes advantage of ASM.JS so likely it will also give you faster performance given the shared policy with the CPU kernels.
Also we provide a rpc interface that allows you to benchmark, tune your code using python by directly connect to your browser

I can see a major obstacle here could be the dependency on the dll content on TVM runtime. We have avoided that by passing in function pointers back into the load dll https://github.com/dmlc/tvm/blob/master/src/runtime/dso_module.cc#L55

So when we build without --system-lib mode, things should not depend on libtvm or libtvm_runtime. The --system-lib mode is intended to bundle the library together with libtvm.dll and other parts. It is not necessary for windows since dll loading is not banned, so we do not have to support this case
another problem on the cuda export (the generated c code) could due to the code generated variable not being explicitly marked as dll export, which hides their symbols. This won't happen in linux

Turns out larger portion of tvm codebase assumes object identity semantics of `==` operator, instead of `logical equality operator`. After I force `__eq__` to the one in `ExprOp`, a bunch of unit tests failed since they assumes `object identity` semantics(as defined in `NodeBase.__eq__`). 

````
======================================================================
ERROR: test_arith_detect_linear_equation.test_basic
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/python2.7/site-packages/nose/case.py", line 197, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File "//tvm/tests/python/unittest/test_arith_detect_linear_equation.py", line 18, in test_basic

    assert m[0] == b  <-------  logical equality operator will fail here since assert will call bool() on the expression, which will cause failure due to ExprOp.__bool__().

  File "/tvm-0.1.0-py2.7-macosx-10.12-intel.egg/tvm/expr.py", line 103, in __nonzero__
    "use tvm.all / tvm.any instead")
ValueError: Cannot use and / or / not operator to Expr, hint: use tvm.all / tvm.any instead
````

I'll look if we can replace the usage of `object identity` with `is` operator, and use `==` for logical equality. This should make it clearer about the meaning of `==`.
